justification: “A notable example is the partial version of the composite face task… The common inference from this task is that holistic processing causes interference between aligned face halves.”
“…including … face inversion (e.g., Yin, 1969).”  This method is listed among the tools “used to test the holistic encoding hypothesis.”
“Various methods … include altering the wholeness of a face through feature displacements (e.g., Tanaka & Farah, 1993).”
“…comparing the recognition of individual parts (e.g., Tanaka & Farah, 1993)” is cited as a way to probe holistic encoding.
“…studying Thatcherized-effects arising from inverting individual features (e.g., Thompson, 1980).”
“…and scrambling the face (e.g., Collishaw & Hole, 2000)… interpreting these differences as indicators of holistic processing.”
“…splitting and misaligning face halves (e.g., Young, Hellawell, & Hay, 1987)… then interpreting these differences as indicators of holistic processing.”

“The composite face task has been particularly useful in testing this hypothesis [failure of selective attention]… observers struggle to ignore irrelevant facial information when making feature-based judgments.”
